channel.title: The Presidency: 1968
channel.description:
Lectures on the 1968 U.S. presidential campaign by political scientist Max Lerner of Brandeis University, presented in late 1968 at Garland Junior College in Boston.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: The Issues and Their Impact, reel 2
item.description: Max Lerner, in the second lecture, discusses how recent events have changed the dynamics of the upcoming election, including the containment of George Wallace and the narrowing gap between Republican candidate Richard Nixon and Democratic candidate Hubert Humphrey.
item.dc:creator: Boston University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: The Issues and Their Impact, reel 1
item.description: Max Lerner, in the second lecture, discusses how recent events have changed the dynamics of the upcoming election, including the containment of George Wallace and the narrowing gap between Republican candidate Richard Nixon and Democratic candidate Hubert Humphrey.
item.dc:creator: Boston University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Behind the Election Results, reel 2
item.description: In his final lecture, Max Lerner analyzes the factors leading to the 1968 presidential election of Richard M. Nixon, including the devastating impact of the turbulent Democratic National Convention in Chicago on Democratic candidate Hubert Humphrey.
item.dc:creator: Boston University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: The Candidates: Style and Character, reel 2
item.description: In the first lecture, Lerner discusses the prospective Democratic and Republican candidates for the presidency and the importance of character in the election. He also assesses the candidacy of George Wallace and the likelihood that it represents a step towards totalitarianism.
item.dc:creator: Boston University
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Behind the Election Results, reel 1
